title: List of Sheffield United F.C. managers
text:
This is a chronological list of <a href="head%20coach">managers</a> of <a href="Sheffield%20United%20F.C.">Sheffield United</a>, a <a href="association%20football">football</a> club based in <a href="Sheffield">Sheffield</a>, England.
United were formed in 1889 as an offshoot of the already existing <a href="Sheffield%20United%20Cricket%20Club">Sheffield United Cricket Club</a> and committee member and club secretary <a href="Joseph%20Wostinholm">JB Wostinholm</a> was placed in charge of team affairs, thus becoming their first 'manager' (although his official title was 'Club secretary'.) The Blades have since had a further twenty eight full-time managers (discounting those appointed on an interim basis).
The club's most successful manager was <a href="John%20Nicholson%20%28football%20secretary%29">John Nicholson</a> who replaced Wostinholm in 1899 and who remained in the post until his death in 1932. Under Nicholson the Blades won the <a href="FA%20Cup">FA Cup</a> four times and established themselves as one of the dominant forces in English football, although winning the Championship for a second time eluded them during that period.
Since Nicholson's death the club have appointed a succession of managers who have enjoyed varying levels of success while the team has generally remained in the top two divisions of English football. The exception was a period of gradual decline during the late 1970s which ultimately saw United relegated to the fourth tier under <a href="Martin%20Peters">Martin Peters</a> in 1981. The club recovered and returned to the top-flight in 1990 under <a href="Dave%20Bassett">Dave Bassett</a>.
A period of relative stability came in 1999 under self confessed Blades fan <a href="Neil%20Warnock">Neil Warnock</a>. He guided the team to two domestic cup semi-finals and a First Division play-off final in the <a href="2002%E2%80%9303%20Sheffield%20United%20F.C.%20season">2002–03 season</a>. Then in the <a href="2005%E2%80%9306%20Sheffield%20United%20F.C.%20season">2005–06 season</a> he guided the team back to the top-flight. They spent just one season in the Premier League and Warnock left the club following the club's relegation.
A chaotic <a href="2010%E2%80%9311%20Sheffield%20United%20F.C.%20season">2010–11 season</a> saw the Blades go through three managers, <a href="Kevin%20Blackwell">Kevin Blackwell</a>, who was assistant manager at United under former manager Neil Warnock. <a href="Gary%20Speed">Gary Speed</a> and another self confessed Blades fan and Sheffield born <a href="Micky%20Adams">Micky Adams</a> as well as <a href="John%20Carver%20%28footballer%29">John Carver</a> who took charge as acting manager for a number of games, the ultimate result of which saw the side relegated to <a href="EFL%20League%20One">League One</a>.
The club remained in the third tier for five years under several managers; Former <a href="Sheffield%20Wednesday%20F.C.">Sheffield Wednesday</a> manager <a href="Danny%20Wilson%20%28footballer%2C%20born%201960%29">Danny Wilson</a>, <a href="Nigel%20Clough">Nigel Clough</a> and <a href="Nigel%20Adkins">Nigel Adkins</a>. Then in 2016 the club turned to <a href="Chris%20Wilder">Chris Wilder</a> who was a former ball boy and former player as well as a Sheffield United fan. In his <a href="2016%E2%80%9317%20Sheffield%20United%20F.C.%20season">first season</a> in charge he took the club back to the second tier finishing 1st with 100 points, a club record for highest points in a season.
In his <a href="2017%E2%80%9318%20Sheffield%20United%20F.C.%20season">second season</a> he got United off to a great start. Having beaten city rivals Sheffield Wednesday with 4–2 at <a href="Hillsborough%20Stadium">Hillsborough</a> (the most goals the club have ever scored in a game at Hillsborough). The team were top of the league and looking for back to back promotions. However the team would finish the season in 10th place, in part due to injuries to key players.
The majority of the club's managers have been English, the only exceptions being <a href="John%20Harris%20%28footballer%20born%201917%29">John Harris</a>, <a href="Ian%20Porterfield">Ian Porterfield</a>, <a href="Billy%20McEwan%20%28footballer%2C%20born%201951%29">Billy McEwan</a> and <a href="David%20Weir%20%28Scottish%20footballer%29">David Weir</a> (all from Scotland), Gary Speed (who was Welsh) and Danny Wilson who has represented <a href="Northern%20Ireland%20national%20football%20team">Northern Ireland</a> at international football. Wilson is also one of two managers to have been manager of United and fierce <a href="Steel%20City%20derby">Steel City</a> rivals Sheffield Wednesday. Wilson was Wednesday's manager in 1998 and also a player for Wednesday in the early 1990s. He was United's manager in 2011. The other manager is <a href="Steve%20Bruce">Steve Bruce</a>, who started his managerial career at Sheffield United as a <a href="Player-coach">player-manager</a> in 1998. Then became Wednesday's manager in 2019.
<a href="Paul%20Heckingbottom">Paul Heckingbottom</a> is the current manager.
Managerial history.
1889–1932: Early days.
At its formation in 1889 United did not employ what would today be termed a <a href="Manager%20%28association%20football%29">manager</a>, the side was coached by a trainer and a football committee selected the team and decided upon tactics (this was a continuation of the structure of <a href="Sheffield%20United%20Cricket%20Club">Sheffield United Cricket Club</a> from which the football team had been formed.) They did appoint <a href="Joseph%20Wostinholm">Joseph Wostinholm</a> to the position of club secretary and he was responsible for the day-to-day running of the club, matchday organisation and dealing with players and contracts. Wostinholm oversaw a period of rapid growth for the team, culminating in 1898 when United won their one and only First Division championship, after which he retired. Wostinholm was replaced by <a href="John%20Nicholson%20%28football%20secretary%29">John Nicholson</a> as secretary and he would remain in post for over 30 years until his death in 1932. Nicholson presided over the most successful period in the club's history as United became a leading force in English football, winning the <a href="FA%20Cup">FA Cup</a> four times and regularly challenged at the top of the league but a second Division One title for the club eluded him.
1932–73: A new era.
Following the death of John Nicholson, who died whilst travelling to an away match in <a href="Birmingham">Birmingham</a>, the United board turned to <a href="Chesterfield%20F.C.">Chesterfield</a> manager <a href="Teddy%20Davison">Teddy Davison</a> to become the club's first real manager. The team were in decline however and were soon relegated for the first time in their history. Davison gradually rebuilt the side with astute signings and young players and regained top-flight status but the club's post-war financial problems would hamper team building for years to come. Davison retired in 1952 and prompted the club to appoint <a href="Rotherham%20United%20F.C.">Rotherham United</a> manager <a href="Reg%20Freeman">Reg Freeman</a> as his successor. Freeman stabilised the team but fell ill and died in 1955, after which United turned to the inexperienced <a href="Joe%20Mercer">Joe Mercer</a> but he struggled to cope with a team in decline and departed for <a href="Aston%20Villa%20F.C.">Aston Villa</a> in 1958. United then appointed <a href="Chester%20F.C.">Chester</a> manager <a href="John%20Harris%20%28Scottish%20footballer%29">John Harris</a> who inherited a talented but under performing side which he transformed into a promotion team, returning to Division One in 1961. Harris built a side based on local players and stabilised them in the top-flight but financial issues soon prompted the sale of key players and United were eventually relegated once more. Harris opted to 'move upstairs' to become 'General Manager', and handed the role of team manager to <a href="Arthur%20Rowley">Arthur Rowley</a> but he was sacked after one season following disappointing results. Harris returned as manager and guided the side to promotion once more but after a good start back in the top-flight Harris' confidence faded and he stepped down in 1973 to 'move upstairs' for the second time.
1973–81: Rapid decline.
Experienced <a href="Blackburn%20Rovers%20F.C.">Blackburn Rovers</a> manager <a href="Ken%20Furphy">Ken Furphy</a> was the man United turned to replace John Harris. He initially did well but the team was ageing and there was little money to replace players, but after a good finish in his first season a disastrous string of results the following year led to Furphy being sacked in October 1975. <a href="Jimmy%20Sirrel">Jimmy Sirrel</a> was recruited from <a href="Notts%20County%20F.C.">Notts County</a> but he proved unpopular with both the players and fans and could not halt the decline, overseeing relegation and then being sacked in September 1977 with United at the bottom of Division Two. The ambitious and colourful <a href="Harry%20Haslam%20%28footballer%2C%20born%201921%29">Harry Haslam</a> was then handed the reins and although many of his ideas were ahead of their time he built an ageing side based on 'star' players at the end of their career. Now in the Third Division performances deteriorated still further and Haslam stepped down due to illness in January 1981. World Cup winner and then United player <a href="Martin%20Peters">Martin Peters</a> was promoted to the position of manager but United were relegated to Division Four at the end of the season and Peters resigned.
1981–95: Moving on up.
With a new ambitious board in place United recruited <a href="Ian%20Porterfield">Ian Porterfield</a> as manager in June 1981. He had an immediate impact, winning the Division Four championship in his first season and taking the club back into the second tier two years later on a meagre budget. Despite this many fans were unhappy with the style of football and Porterfield was sacked in 1986 following supporter protests. Coach <a href="Billy%20McEwan%20%28footballer%2C%20born%201951%29">Billy McEwan</a> was promoted to the position of manager but failed to improve the standard of play and with attendances falling and the team in danger of relegation once more he was sacked in January 1988. United now turned to the colourful character of <a href="Dave%20Bassett">Dave Bassett</a> who had most recently had a short, unsuccessful spell as manager of <a href="Watford%20F.C.">Watford</a>. It was to prove an astute appointment as although he could not prevent relegation in his first season he built a solid, hard working team on a small budget and won back to back promotions, returning the club to the top-flight and achieving regular mid-table finishes. With the formation of the <a href="Premier%20League">Premier League</a> United's old financial problems and willingness to sell star players without replacing them meant the side eventually succumbed to relegation and when an immediate return was not forthcoming Basset was sacked in December 1995.
1995–present: Comings and goings.
The following years proved a turbulent time for United as they chased the ambition of Premiership football. Experienced <a href="Howard%20Kendall">Howard Kendall</a> was recruited as manager and undertook a complete rebuilding of the side but left in June 1997 to take over at <a href="Everton%20F.C.">Everton</a>. Player-coach <a href="Nigel%20Spackman">Nigel Spackman</a> was promoted to replace Kendall but after initial promise he quit after only eight months citing boardroom interference. This was to become a recurring theme and replacement <a href="Steve%20Bruce">Steve Bruce</a> would leave after only one season citing the same reasons. <a href="Adrian%20Heath">Adrian Heath</a> then proved a disastrous appointment and lasted only six months before being sacked with United looking more likely to be relegated than promoted. The Blades then turned to experienced lower league manager <a href="Neil%20Warnock">Neil Warnock</a> who managed to stave off relegation and began to rebuild the side on a meagre budget. Warnock proved a divisive figure with fans but after a number of mid-table finishes he achieved promotion back to the Premiership in 2006 but the side were poor the following season and were relegated, prompting the board not to renew Warnock's contract.
Just like Adrian Heath, the appointment of <a href="Bryan%20Robson">Bryan Robson</a> in 2007 proved an unpopular and unsuccessful one and he was sacked after less than a year following poor results and intense fan pressure. Former assistant manager <a href="Kevin%20Blackwell">Kevin Blackwell</a> was appointed as Robson's replacement, but despite reaching the play-off finals in his first full season the team was obviously in decline and he was sacked after only two games of the 2010–11 season. Worse was to come however as player-coach <a href="Gary%20Speed">Gary Speed</a> was briefly promoted to manager, but left after only a few months to take over <a href="Wales%20national%20football%20team">the Welsh national side</a>. <a href="Micky%20Adams">Micky Adams</a> then became the third full-time manager of the season and oversaw a disastrous run of results which saw United relegated and Adams sacked after only six months in charge. With United in the third tier once more <a href="Danny%20Wilson%20%28footballer%2C%20born%201960%29">Danny Wilson</a> was appointed as manager in June 2011, despite protests from United fans over his previous association with cross-town rivals <a href="Sheffield%20Wednesday%20F.C.">Sheffield Wednesday</a>. He guided the club to the <a href="2012%20Football%20League%20One%20play-off%20Final">League One play-off final</a> in his first full season in charge, losing to <a href="Huddersfield%20Town%20A.F.C.">Huddersfield Town</a>. Despite the club challenging for promotion the following season, a poor run of results led to Wilson's departure in April 2013, being replaced by <a href="Chris%20Morgan%20%28footballer%29">Chris Morgan</a> until the end of the season. After a long search for a new boss former Scotland defender <a href="David%20Weir%20%28Scottish%20footballer%29">David Weir</a> was appointed as Wilson's long-term replacement. His tenure was short-lived however, as he was sacked the following October after winning only one game from thirteen in charge. After Chris Morgan had overseen the team for a brief time, <a href="Nigel%20Clough">Nigel Clough</a> was appointed as Weir's permanent successor in October 2013.
Assistant managers.
<a href="Archie%20Clark%20%28footballer%29">Archie Clark</a> was the first person to be officially appointed assistant manager of Sheffield United in 1958. Since then United have appointed a further 24 people to the position, with <a href="Gary%20Crosby%20%28footballer%29">Gary Crosby</a> post-holder. Of the club's assistant managers, four of them (Martin Peters, Adrian Heath, Nigel Spackman and Kevin Blackwell) were subsequently appointed to the position of manager on a full-time basis, while a further three (Archie Clark, <a href="Cec%20Coldwell">Cec Coldwell</a> twice and <a href="Russell%20Slade">Russell Slade</a> twice) took the role on a caretaker basis. <a href="Steve%20Thompson%20%28footballer%2C%20born%201955%29">Steve Thompson</a> made the reverse transition, having a spell as acting manager in 1997 before being appointed as joint assistant manager to Steve Bruce a year later.
